page.title: 03HOUSING
page.content: Morland had three main growth periods. The first permanent stone built houses and farms date from about 1700 and were constructed of local limestone and mortar with "imported"sandstone for door and window surrounds and slates for the roof.Many of these buildings were village farms that had a house,byre and stable and a larger barn attached.There are at least twelve of these "in" farms remaining. The second growth period was about 1950 when council houses were built. The builders took great care to make these fit into the traditional pattern. During the past twenty years a sewerage system was installed that gave rise to a large number of mixed dwellings being erected.The Council have insisted they all fit the pattern
